Step.name: Indicators of Institutional Abuse
Step.html: Lack of privacy, dignity or choice for individual care practices.

Step.name: Indicators of Institutional Abuse
Step.html: Strict, regimented or inflexible routines or schedules for daily activities such as meal times, bed/awakening times, bathing/washing, going to the toilet.

Step.name: Indicators of Institutional Abuse
Step.html: Unwelcoming, stark surroundings and lack of stimulation.

Step.name: The Dignity Challenge
Step.html:
The dignity challenge is a national campaign to promote best standards of care in services for adults at risk. The challenge encourages carers to meet 10 key standards which include:-

•Have a zero tolerance of all forms of abuse

•Support people with the same respect you would want for yourself or a member of your family

•Treat each person as an individual by offering a personalised service

•Enable people to maintain the maximum possible level of independence, choice and control

•Listen & support people to express their needs & wants

•Respect People's Right to Privacy

•Ensure People feel able to complain without fear of retribution

•Engage with family members and carers as care partners

•Assist people to maintain confidence and a positive self-esteem

•Act to alleviate people's loneliness and isolation.

Step.name: Institutional Abuse
Step.html:
Institutional abuse is the mistreatment of people bought about by poor or inadequate care or support or systematic poor practice that affects the whole care setting.

It occurs when the individual’s wishes and needs are sacrificed for the smooth running of a group, service or organisation.

It is more likely to occur where staff are inadequately trained, poorly supervised, not supported by management and have poor communication skills. The institution operates a 'closed' culture, for example a care setting where new ideas, visitors, care management or other professional involvement is discouraged.

Institutional abuse can happen in hospitals, care and nursing homes and in the practices of domiciliary care agencies.

Step.name: Scenario
Step.html:
You visit a care home and notice that the staff begin changing the service users into their night clothes at 6pm. There are ‘set’ bath times and a rota for the hairdresser on the message board. What are your concerns?

Answer

It might be that some service users choose to change this early but very unlikely that they all want to! Also the practises seem very rigid and lack individual choices. The home would need to be investigated further.
